title: ‘Half alive’: Sole survivor of Australia’s mushroom murders tells court of grief
description: A pastor who survived a deadly mushroom lunch with killer Erin Patterson has opened up about life without his wife, who died from the meal.
content:
The only guest to survive a toxic mushroom lunch with murderer said on Monday he felt “half alive” without his wife, who was one of the three victims.

Pastor Ian Wilkinson wept in court as he spoke of the loss of his wife, Heather, after she ate a beef Wellington dish laced with death cap mushrooms – the world’s deadliest fungi.

Patterson, 50, was convicted last month of serving the poisonous fare to her husband’s parents, aunt and uncle at a sumptuous lunch in her rural home in the state of Victoria in 2023.

Within days, the parents and aunt were dead, but the uncle – Ian Wilkinson – survived after weeks in hospital to give testimony at his host’s murder trial, which became a global media sensation.

Patterson was present in the Supreme Court of Victoria in Melbourne for the two-day hearing, set aside for relatives to testify to the impact of her crimes and for lawyers to argue over the severity of her sentencing.
summary: The sole survivor of Australia's notorious mushroom murders, Pastor Ian Wilkinson, said he felt "half alive" without his wife, Heather, who was one of the three victims. The meat was served at a lavish dinner hosted by Patricia Patterson, a 50-year-old woman convicted of orchestrating the murders. The victims were their parents, aunt and uncle, but within days they were dead. The trial of Patricia Patterson led to a global media sensation.
shortSummary: The sole survivor of the infamous 1993/2000s Australian mushroom murders, Heather Smith, told of her loss at 37:00 GMT: "We're still alive."
argos_summary: In Victoria, Australia, a woman named Patterson was convicted of poisoning her husband's family with death cap mushrooms during a 2023 lunch, killing three relatives while the uncle, Pastor Ian Wilkinson, survived after weeks in hospital. He testified in court, describing his wife's death and his own near‑death experience, and the case drew global media attention. The trial, held in Melbourne's Supreme Court, focused on the impact of the crimes and sentencing. The case highlights the lethal danger of toxic mushrooms and the personal tragedy for the surviving family.
